avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger is moderate above 1800 m, below that altitude danger is low. 
Up to summit level glide-snow avalanches can trigger naturally at any time of day, esp. on steep slopes with smooth ground (grass, rocks) in all aspects. Avalanches mostly small. 
On leeward slopes, small snowdrift accumulations are being freshly generated. Avalanches can be triggered even by 1 person on steep shady slopes. There are only few danger zones.

avalancheProblems.comment: steep grassy slopes, possible at any time of day (also size 2)

snowpackStructure.comment:
The fresh snow settled somewhat amid rising temperatures (sink-in depths 10-15 cm) and the proneness to triggering has receded. Weak layers are evident inside the fresh fallen snow wherever snowdrifts lie deposited on top of fresh snow. In some places, surface hoar has been blanketed over.
The snowpack base is stable and thoroughly wet up to intermediate altitudes. The warm ground leads to the entire snowpack gliding downhill over smooth ground.

tendency.comment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

weatherForecast.comment:
On Tuesday night a bit of rainfall (above 1600-2000 m snowfall) is possible.
During the daytime on Wednesday, high-altitude clouds, frequent sunshine, diffuse light conditions. The W/SW winds will be moderate to strong (40 km/hr). At 2000 m: 0 degrees; at 3000 m: -6 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanche danger above the treeline is moderate, below that altitude danger is low.
Fresh drifts cna be triggered as small-to-medium slab avalanches by 1 person on N/SE facing slopes. Danger zones occur in gullies, bowls and behind discontinuities, near to and distant from ridges. Frequency and size of danger zones increase swiftly with ascending altitude.
Up to 2600 m glide-snow avalanches can trigger naturally at any time of day on very steep slopes with smooth ground surfaces. Avoid zones below glide cracks.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Trigger-sensitive drifts due to stormy S/W winds

avalancheProblems.comment: ridges, gullies, steep bowls, also distant from ridgelines
steep grassy slopes, possible at any time of day, sometimes deep fractures in Tauern

snowpackStructure.comment:
On Sunday night, the fresh snow settled somewhat amid rising temperatures (sink-in depths 10-15 cm) and the proneness to triggering has receded. Weak layers are evident inside the fresh fallen snow wherever snowdrifts lie deposited on top of fresh snow. In some places, surface hoar has been blanketed over. Crusts and faceted layers lurk in the old snowpack on shady slopes, as tests confirm. The snowpack is highly irregular, making weak layers small.
The snowpack base is stable and thoroughly wet up to intermediate altitudes. The warm ground leads to the entire snowpack gliding downhill over smooth ground.

tendency.comment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

weatherForecast.comment:
On Tuesday night a bit of rainfall (above 1600-2000 m snowfall) is possible.
During the daytime on Wednesday, high-altitude clouds, frequent sunshine, diffuse light conditions. The W/SW winds will be moderate to strong (40 km/hr). At 2000 m: 0 degrees; at 3000 m: -6 degrees.
